title: The Five Doctors
goofs: When frozen, the Brigadier moves his head to watch Borusa go.
When he attacks the Brigadier, the Cyberman's jeans are visible.
The Cybermen following the Master must be blind not to see the Doctor.
Sarah gets into trouble rolling down a very gentle slope.

continuity_notes.name: Death Zone
continuity_notes.description: A place on Gallifrey where aliens were kidnapped for sport before Rassilon's time.
continuity_notes.current_status: Active in the story, containing various alien beings

continuity_notes.name: Rassilon
continuity_notes.description: Legendary Time Lord who either created or ended the Death Zone games
continuity_notes.current_status: Deceased, but his consciousness remains in the Dark Tower

continuity_notes.name: Borusa
continuity_notes.description: Time Lord seeking immortality through the Game of Rassilon
continuity_notes.current_status: Encased in stone as a result of winning the game

continuity_notes.name: The Master
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's nemesis, brought to the Death Zone by the Time Lords

technobabble: The Time Lords plan to get the Master into the Death Zone by means of a 'power-boosted open-ended transmat beam'
The third Doctor notes: 'I've reversed the polarity of the neutron flow.'
roots: La Belle et le Bête (Borusa's fate)
links: The Doctor reaches the Eye of Orion (mentioned in 'The King's Demons'), before being drawn to Gallifrey.
Phantom images of Mike Yates, Liz Shaw, Jamie and Zoe appear to the Doctors within the Dark Tower.

locations.name: Eye of Orion
locations.description: A peaceful location visited by the Doctor
locations.current_status: Briefly shown at the beginning of the episode

locations.name: Earth
locations.description: Home planet of the Doctor's human companions

locations.name: Gallifrey
locations.description: Home planet of the Time Lords
locations.current_status: Main setting for the episode, featuring the Death Zone and Dark Tower

untold_adventures: The Doctor tells the Brigadier about 'the terrible Zodin' (see 'Attack of the Cybermen').
qv: The Origins of the Time Lords
additional_notes: The canonicity of 'Shada' is discussed in relation to this episode.
bottom_line: A fine anniversary tale, although don't analyse the plot too closely as it's largely a collection of set-pieces without a great deal of substance. This is Terrance Dicks' loving tribute to a series that he helped to mould and, as such, contains everything that it should. Richard Hurndall does a passable William Hartnell.
